drupalNodeEvent.title: Frontiers in Chinese Studies - “Man Proposes, Heaven Disposes”: The Political Logic of Succession in Imperial China

field_speakers.processed: Duancheng Yang楊端程, Lecturer, East China University of Politics and Law (dcyang@ecupl.edu.cn)

field_organizers.processed: Organized by Song Chen With Support from the China Institute at Bucknell University

field_description.processed:
This study is based on a database encompassing all instances of political succession in imperial China, constructed by the speaker from a large collection of historical sources. The analysis reveals that only half of the designated successors in the two millennia of imperial Chinese history successfully ascended to power. These divergent outcomes are best explained by the age of the ruling monarch, the age gap between the ruling monarch and the designated successor, and the presence or absence of powerful officials at court. These findings the conventional wisdom that uses primogeniture to explain political succession and instead emphasizes the influence of non-institutional factors. (Co-authors: Haibing Yan and Jiawei Fu)

Time: 7–8 p.m. (US Eastern Time), Wednesday, November 13, 2024
